I have heard that face masks stop viruses when randomized clinical studies do not confirm that 😅but science before "pandemic" is invalid 😉

“There is low certainty evidence from nine trials (3507 participants) that wearing a mask may make little or no difference to the outcome of influenza‐like illness (ILI) compared to not wearing a mask (risk ratio (RR) 0.99, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.82 to 1.18. There is moderate certainty evidence that wearing a mask probably makes little or no difference to the outcome of laboratory‐confirmed influenza compared to not wearing a mask (RR 0.91, 95% CI 0.66 to 1.26; 6 trials; 3005 participants)…the pooled results of randomised trials did not show a clear reduction in respiratory viral infection with the use of medical/surgical masks during seasonal influenza.” - Physical interventions to interrupt or reduce the spread of respiratory viruses, Jefferson, 2020

https://www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD006207.pub5/full

The validation tests of such masks are done with perfect sealing including additional material like silicone. This is completely unrealistic for 8h, everyday use at the supermarket cashout desk or in the library. So the realistic share of the breath air actually passing through the filter needs to be determined. Next, the masks ability to store and hold the virus must be determined and at which point the amount stored will become harmful to the wearer from re-aspiration. Next, blood gas analysis needs to be done to find out if and when acidosis is occurring and how much stress is caused to the cardiovascular system. This will result in a use time limitation and exchange intervals.

There's much more to it - you have to identify the point when the mask is soaked through and the virus replicates in it and on its outside, from where it's vaping into the environment.

Bottom line: those very isolated, lab-based considerations have no value in epidemiologic questions. Human beings are designed by nature to breathe off germs and therefore exist in an environment that's including germs. Trying to fight this with brute force is a medical suicide mission and will fail.

During the pandemic here in parts of Australia, we were encouraged to wear surgical masks instead of N95 for a couple of fairly good reasons.

1. The primary goal of collective mask wearing was to limit the expelling of cough-generated aerosols. This is particularly important given the high chance for asymptomatic individuals to perform normal activities in public.
2. But reinforcing the first point, the emphasis was not on protecting oneself (selfishly) but to think about your impact on others. This is one reason why so many years after SARS, many people in Asian countries that were impacted would immediately wear a mask at the first sign of an illness (to limit the chance to spread to others). Generally speaking many Asian countries (such as Japan) practice collectivism rather than individualism, which helps greatly in this case.
3. Many N95 masks contain exhalation valves. The wearing of such a mask would defeat the purpose of limiting the spread, because a cough from an individual wearing such a mask would lead to cough-generated aerosols leaving the mask (this is also why the CDC does not recommend them)
4. If the general public uses N95 masks, it depletes the stock for medical staff who require daily use of PPE.

N95 are relatively efficient, provided they are rated NIOSH, but with major defects in terms of comfort and health issues for prolonged wear! https://blogs.cdc.gov/niosh-science-blog/2020/09/08/source-control/

Here is one of the most extensive studies:

Objective: We aimed to examine the efficacy of medical masks and respirators in protecting against respiratory infections using pooled data from two homogenous randomised control clinical trials (RCTs):

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28799710/

Results: Rates of all outcomes were consistently lower in the continuous N95 and/or targeted N95 arms. In adjusted analysis, rates of laboratory-confirmed bacterial colonisation (RR 0.33, 95% CI 0.21-0.51), laboratory-confirmed viral infections (RR 0.46, 95% CI 0.23-0.91) and droplet-transmitted infections (RR 0.26, 95% CI 0.16-0.42) were significantly lower in the continuous N95 arm. Laboratory-confirmed influenza was also lowest in the continuous N95 arm (RR 0.34, 95% CI 0.10-1.11), but the difference was not statistically significant. Rates of laboratory-confirmed bacterial colonisation (RR 0.54, 95% CI 0.33-0.87) and droplet-transmitted infections (RR 0.43, 95% CI 0.25-0.72) were also lower in the targeted N95 arm, but not in medical mask arm.

11) List of studies from 1981 to 2015 on the ineffectiveness of face masks to prevent infection:
Neil Orr’s study, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2493952/pdf/annrcse01509-0009.pdf
published in 1981 in the Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of
England. Dr. Orr was a surgeon in the Severalls Surgical Unit in
Colchester. And for six months, from March through August 1980, the
surgical staff in that unit decided to see what would happen if they did
not wear masks during surgeries. They wore no masks for six months, and
compared the rate of surgical wound infections from March through
August 1980 with the rate of wound infections from March through August
of the previous four years. And they discovered, to their amazement,
that when nobody wore masks during surgeries, the rate of wound
infections was less than half what it was when everyone wore masks.
Conclusion: “It would appear that minimum contamination can best be
achieved by not wearing a mask at all” and that wearing a mask during
surgery “is a standard procedure that could be abandoned.”

Masks are useless in preventing the spread of disease and, if anything,
are unsanitary objects that themselves spread bacteria and viruses.
Masks get touched regularly, sneezed in, coughed in, and create sweat
and moisture which all create unnecessary contamination to be inhaled,
again and again.

In Tunevall’s 1991 study,
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01658736 a general surgical
team wore no masks in half of their surgeries for two years. After 1,537
operations performed with masks, the wound infection rate was 4.7%,
while after 1,551 operations performed without masks, the wound
infection rate was only 3.5%.

A review by Skinner and Sutton in 2001
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0310057X0102900402
concluded that “The evidence for discontinuing the use of surgical face
masks would appear to be stronger than the evidence available to support
their continued use.”

Lahme et al., in 2001, https://europepmc.org/article/med/11760479 wrote
that “surgical face masks worn by patients during regional anaesthesia,
did not reduce the concentration of airborne bacteria over the operation
field in our study.”

Figueiredo et al., in 2001,
http://www.advancesinpd.com/adv01/21Figueiredo.htm reported that in five
years of doing peritoneal dialysis without masks, rates of peritonitis
in their unit were no different.

Your intro from timestamp 0 to 0:08 quoting blm 'racial inequality ' for black accounting for 34% civic deaths in a population of 13% is misleading and uninformed. It does not take into account other uncontrollable factors which contribute to the result. For instance: the covid-19 Corona virus utilizes the CD26 receptor, also known as the ACEr2 which is a cell receptor the virus utilizes to enter host cells, similar to the CD4 or CCR5 receptor for HIV. The number of this receptor varies with age, race and other epidemiologic factors accounting for variances in its pathogenicity. For instance, children, especially infants have very low receptor numbers, which then increase with age. This explains the low rates of infection and disease severity in this age group. Less #'s of host receptors = less viral load = less severe infection and disease symptoms.
For blm to blame 'systemic racial inequality ' of covid-19 is ungrounded, spurious and unscientific. It only results in inciting divisiveness which fails everyone.

Why have you ignored the health concerns of breathing-in your own exhaled breath when wearing an N95 mask?

According to the online Occupational Health & Safety magazine, based in Texas (https://ohsonline.com) the rating for Carbon dioxide levels is as follows:
250-300 ppm (parts per million): background (normal) outdoor level
350-1,000 ppm: typical level found in occupied spaces with good air exchange
1,000-2,000 ppm: level associated with headaches, sleepiness, and stagnant, stale stuff air; poor concentration, loss of attention, increased heart rate and slight nausea may also be present.
5,000 plus ppm: This indicates unusual air conditions where high levels of other gasses also could be present. Toxicity or oxygen deprivation could occur. This is the permissible limit for daily workplace exposure.
Note 'LIMIT'
Now compare those figures quoted above to https://www.bitchute.com/video/ypLjmXQoLygi/ in which a child who is doing nothing but standing still, i.e. not exerting himself, has CO2 levels measured inside a variety of face covering.
Here are the results for the N95 mask:
Within 10-12 seconds CO2 levels reach 2300 plus ppm
Within 20 seconds CO2 levels reach 5000 plus ppm
Within 25 seconds CO2 levels reach 7000 ppm
Within 30 seconds CO2 levels reach 8000 ppm
The results speak for themselves

While Black Americans make up ~13% of the population but account for ~34% of Covid-19 deaths I don't believe that this is racial inequality but rather our healthcare system. As of 2010 20% of Black Americans were uninsured, 34% had Medicaid, and 46% had Employer or Privet insurance. While 13% of White Americans were uninsured, 15% were on Medicaid, and 72% had Employer or Private insurance. 33% of Hispanic Americans were uninsured (50% being non US citizens), 29% were on Medicaid, and 39% Employer. Could it be that people with better insurance receive better treatment? Blacks Americans also tend to have diabetes, hypertension, and asthma that could contribute to the death rate being higher. They are likely to live in densely populated areas. There is no way to tell how much they practiced social distancing or any other precautions. There's a lot of other factors other than systemic racial inequalities. It's sad for all who lost their lives due to Covid-19. All Lives Matter.

Hear me out: the propaganda posted at the beginning of this video is such because it ignores the content of the linked information (which itself is incomplete to prove the point being made).

For those curious:
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/data/racial-data-transparency
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0002934320304125

Comparing all blacks to all whites has the same issues with comparing all women to all men in income. Female CEOs actually on average make more than male CEOs: https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2018/05/25/women-ceos-still-rarity-but-pay-tops-men/644914002/#:~:text=Women%20make%20up%20only%205,done%20for%20The%20Associated%20Press.

Comparing all of a group to all of another group makes several fatal assumption errors: the groups ought to be the same, any difference should be explained as racial/sexual discrimination rather than some fundamental difference between groups (dieses susceptibility is not equally distributed and can be explained by genetic differences and economic stratification), and it ignores the differences within the groups (like an economic breakdown poor white vs poor black, rural vs urban concerns, personality differences matters in job selection, personal preference distribution within groups, etc.).

While I fully endorse that black lives matters (I don't support all the initiatives of the group #blacklivesmatters though: its possible to support a cause and not support a group pushing specific policies) pushing propaganda devoid of the nuance necessary to make a difference will ultimately hurt those you are trying to help.

The poor today in the US face very similar challenges even if minorities are disproportionally impacted by poverty: https://www.apa.org/pi/ses/resources/publications/minorities

Then there is the welfare trap: https://www.cato.org/blog/new-study-finds-more-evidence-poverty-traps-welfare-system
which, while not racist itself, will impact the poor who happen to be mainly minorities. And being poor is a genuine health issue: https://www.healthpovertyaction.org/news-events/key-facts-poverty-and-poor-health/#:~:text=Poverty%20is%20both%20a%20cause,most%20vulnerable%20people%20each%20year.

Claiming systemic racism is easy to do but itself doesn't offer an actionable solution. Most policies aimed at alleviating poverty have all but failed (and one could argue that it is likely due to the chronic oversimplification of the issue): https://www.huduser.gov/Periodicals/CITYSCPE/VOL3NUM3/article3.pdf

There are real negative psychological health impacts by framing the issue as "systemic". It should be obvious that systemic changes are much more difficult to address and this will lead to a victimhood mentality. This can easily lead to a concept called "Social defeat" which will kick off a vicious feedback loop.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S016517811400078X
https://bmcresnotes.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13104-019-4758-2#:~:text=Mental%20defeat%20describes%20a%20state,development%20and%20chronification%20%5B2%5D.
https://www.goodtherapy.org/blog/emotional-perception-influences-how-people-cope-defeat-1211112/

So stop virtue signaling to appease your own social status. The fact that blacks are more likely to die from covid is primarily economic (though there are SOME pre-dispositional issues which isn't a result of racism but are a result of genetic realities and cultural/lifestyle choices).

For those upset about the opening BLM blurb, there is often confusion with the "racial inequality" phrase, especially when it is prefaced by "systemic".
The referenced article doesn't imply systemic racism. It points out the racial differences between blacks and whites and that those differences are caused by many things (e.g. cultural choices, economic and physiological differences, etc.), and that those differences lead to differences in life expectancy.
I guess the same argument could be made for systemic gender inequality because males and females have different life expectancies.
All that said, I think the blurb is being used by some to imply racism.

 First od all, while you put your references on the screen, you didn't put them in limk form in the description. For those who want to check them:
1) https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/data/racial-data-transarency - but it's 404 for me. :/ I tried to get to the source using citation in 2), but couldn't do it.
2) https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0002934320304125

 Now, about the article 2). Besides problematic source 1), I have two issues:

 1. You cite the article to support the claim that higher mortality is a result of systemic racism. This article didn't convince me of that. The only thing it did was comparing current situation to older similar cases, but even if I grant that thhose past cases were indeed cause by systemic racism, this doesn't prove yet that COVID-19 case was. What causes uneven death distribution during one pandemic doesn't carry over to another pandemic; this has to be proven with specific evidence, not just comparisons.

 The article also contains the sentence that "Quantitatively, it is plausible that this large mag-nitude of increase of COVID-19 is an overestimate. Qualita-tively, however, based on the existing totality of evidence,4-11the observation is real..." - but citations 4-11 also make comparisons to other cases.

 2. The article doesn't mention the ratio of COVID-19 cases in blacks compared to whites. If blacks for some reason were getting COVID-19 3 times as frequently as whites, then we would indeed expect 3x mortality rate. That would of course still be a problem, but a slightly different one.

 Now some clarifications about my position. I don't live in US, and therefore, I don't know if there is systemic racism in US. In this comment, I don't claim that mortality disproportion, if real, is not caused by systemic racism - I don't know that. I also don't say that this article is worthles - it discusses various solutions to the (potential) problem.
My issue is that the article isn't convincing enough to say that the problem really exists, and with you citing the source that doesn't really support your claim .

The primary video is interesting, but I'm having trouble understanding the statement you made at the beginning. You claimed that the over-representation of black victims of COVID-19 is "a result of systemic racial inequalities in the US" and linked https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0002934320304125, however reading through the article is doesn't make this claim at all. The article says that we need to do further research to understand the cause of over-representation of black victims and suggests that it MIGHT be caused by racial inequalities, then provides several historical examples of racial inequalities (hepatocellular cancer mortality was improved by a prohibitively expensive drug, and a treatment for syphilis was intentionally withheld back in 1932). But never once do they provide concrete evidence that the current over-representation is due to systemic inequality.
I think it's very important not to stoke racial fires (which are already swelling across the nation) without hard proof that there's actually a causal link between systemic racism and the problems you're addressing. Riling people into protests and riots over racism when racism isn't at fault will only breed civil distrust and prevent us from finding and solving the REAL underlying cause. It's possible that there are genetic factors at play. For instance: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0001706X15000820?via%3Dihub some ethnic groups are less susceptible to Malaria than others. There could also be cultural factors at play. Jews are also disproportionately affected by COVID-19 (in New York alone 700 Jews have died from COVID-19 out of 2 million, a total of 0.00035% of the Jewish population -- TEN TIMES the average death rate in America). When you consider that the mayor of New York issued a formal statement to Jewish citizens to stop congregating, it seems potentially relevant. Perhaps black communities are less likely to obey stay-at-home orders or self-quarantine. It's also possible the issue isn't a RACIAL one, but one of INCOME INEQUALITY. If the issue is a matter of access to funds and healthcare then claiming the problem is due to racism will never solve the issue: because you'll villify white business owners who had a chance at giving jobs to people in poverty but are now destitute themselves.

In re your intro ... While I'm sure that racial injustice is part of the reason why covid-19 has infected people of color at a disproportionate rate, it is NOT the ONLY reason. Every cell in the human body has receptors for Vitamin D, and it plays a huge role in our immune system. A large number of North Americans are Vitamin D deficient, and the darker one's skin, the less Vitamin D a person will make when exposed to the sun. Supplementation is an inexpensive intervention, and overdoses are very rare. Personally, I think everyone should be taking several thousand IU's per day to decrease their chance of developing covid-19.

It would be interesting to see the Vitamin D status of covid-19 patients of every color, to see how much of an impact it's having.
